paragraphs.title: The Context
paragraphs.text:
%md
The fundamental problem involves finding the path between *low level* computational data and *high level* meaning for the user:
$$
[\text{user meaning}] \\\
\uparrow \uparrow \\\ 
?\\\
\uparrow \uparrow\\\ 
[\text{computational data}]
$$
For learning analytics, we are looking for a path from the representation of a learners writing to analytics that provide meaningful feedback. At the lowest level the text is the writing, but we are interested in a relation (\\(R\\) between *analytics* and *learning*. When working with *text analytics*, we are in a computational domain. When working with *writing* for *learning* (or learning to write), we are in a pedagogical domain.
$$
[\text{learning}] \leftarrow R \rightarrow [\text{analytics}]\\\
\uparrow \uparrow \\\ 
\uparrow \uparrow\\\
[\text{writing}] \leftrightarrow [\text{text}]
$$
**Important Note:**A connection between the writing and the text connect does not necessarily result in a connection between analytics and learning.


> Discuss this session online in the [LASI-17 Room](https://gitter.im/writing-analytics/LASI-17) of the Gitter [Writing Analytics Community](https://gitter.im/writing-analytics).

$$

paragraphs.title: Loading data
paragraphs.text:
//Load news example from S3
val pharmText = S3Files.get("pharm-sample.txt")

msg.data:
pharmText: String =
Before I went on placement in XXXX in the Summer break, I didn’t know how much the pharmacy means in the day-to-day life of the average elderly person, but also how important HMR is, and how it can save lives. I was familiar with the usual aspects of being older: more medical conditions that leads to more medications which leads to more medications being forgotten and the vicious cycle that ensues, but to see how this actually played out in everyday practice, with the consequences that it entailed, was eye opening, sad and exciting all at once.
We had one case of an elderly gentleman (and he really was a gentle man)- Mr DA, who had been baffling his doctors and the pharmacy for months about his fluctuating INR. No one could work out what it was, and it was only after...

Before I went on placement in XXXX in the Summer break, I didn’t know how much the pharmacy means in the day-to-day life of the average elderly person, but also how important HMR is, and how it can save lives. I was familiar with the usual aspects of being older: more medical conditions that leads to more medications which leads to more medications being forgotten and the vicious cycle that ensues, but to see how this actually played out in everyday practice, with the consequences that it entailed, was eye opening, sad and exciting all at once.
We had one case of an elderly gentleman (and he really was a gentle man)- Mr DA, who had been baffling his doctors and the pharmacy for months about his fluctuating INR. No one could work out what it was, and it was only after placement when I rang to enquire as to how this gentleman was going for my case review that I found out that an HMR had been done (finally after multiple requests to the GP) and Mr DA had been intermittently taking fish oil without telling anyone. Mr DA would take a fish oil every other day or so, for a few days, when he remembered, which was a bit patchy at the best of times. As a result his INR would go up and then his warfarin would need to change in his Webster pa

paragraphs.title: Display a document
Cleaning
paragraphs.text:
// Clean the document
val cleanText = {
    val cleanText:String = tapServer.cleanText(pharmText).results.head
    println("length of clean text: "+cleanText.length)
    println("length of original text: "+pharmText.length)
    val cleanSet = cleanText.toList.toSet
    val origSet = pharmText.toList.toSet
    val removed = origSet.diff(cleanSet).map(c =>  "\\u%04X".format(c.toInt))
    println("Characters removed: "+removed.mkString(", "))
    println("-------------------------------------------- ")
    cleanText
}

paragraphs.title: Unstructured to structured

msg.data:
Original text:
 Hello, this is a test for structure.

This should be a new section.

And this should be the final section.

paragraphs.title: A Hypothesis that relates
paragraphs.text:
%md
Finding a relationship between learner meaning and low level feature representations in the text
Skewness of descriptive statistics can be an indicator of the balance of uniqueness of words in a text
Typical writing has a characteristic shape
Deviation from this pattern may indicate a-typical writing
Identification of a-typical writing may be helpful for the learner (or educator)

msg.data:
Finding a relationship between learner meaning and low level feature representations in the text
Skewness of descriptive statistics can be an indicator of the balance of uniqueness of words in a text
Typical writing has a characteristic shape
Deviation from this pattern may indicate a-typical writing
Identification of a-typical writing may be helpful for the learner (or educator)

2CHBDJGUA:shared_process.name: pharmText
object: Before I went on placement in XXXX in the Summer break, I didn’t know how much the pharmacy means in the day-to-day life of the average elderly person, but also how important HMR is, and how it can save lives. I was familiar with the usual aspects of being older: more medical conditions that leads to more medications which leads to more medications being forgotten and the vicious cycle that ensues, but to see how this actually played out in everyday practice, with the consequences that it entailed, was eye opening, sad and exciting all at once.

We had one case of an elderly gentleman (and he really was a gentle man)- Mr DA, who had been baffling his doctors and the pharmacy for months about his fluctuating INR. No one could work out what it was, and it was only after placement when I rang to enquire as to how this gentleman was going for my case review that I found out that an HMR had been done (finally after multiple requests to the GP) and Mr DA had been intermittently taking fish oil without telling anyone. Mr DA would take a fish oil every other day or so, for a few days, when he remembered, which was a bit patchy at the best of times. As a result his INR would go up and then his warfarin would need to change in his Webster pack that we would pack for him, and then he would forget to take the fish oil for a while and his INR would go down, and his warfarin dose would need to change again- It was IT1 week 3 Cardiovascular right in front of my eyes!

However, most surprisingly to me, it highlighted and challenged my ideas about the importance of HMR (which I had learnt about in theory in PS2). While learning about HMR in PS2 I skeptical that having a medication review in the home would really contribute much to the report, and really that it was a bit of a gimmick. After all, medications are the same whether they are in the pharmacy or in the home.... Right? This case brought home the importance of seeing the medications in situ, as the fish oil was only found out about once it was seen in the cupboard along side Mr DA’s usual Webster pack. It could be said that the HMR potentially saved the life of this patient, as his fish oil is now being packed, and being taken consistently and the INR has settled.

I also came to see the effects of once cognitive impairment starts to set in from an objective point of view, which I wasn’t able to see previously. I saw from a pharmacist’s point of view how it becomes infinitely more difficult to help patients with self-managing their medication especially if non-intentional non-adherence becomes a problem. Mr DA wasn’t able to tell us that he was on fish oil, as he forgot that he had it, and that in itself presented as a fluctuating INR. He would also forget to take his medication from his Webster packs for weeks at a time also, returning the full, unused packs of Websters back to the pharmacy. This non-intentional non-adherence (as we learnt in PS2) was having therapeutic repercussions, probably compounding his medication related issues many times over.

However, the situation also brought back memories for me, of my father in his dementia having scripts filled with boxes of medications around the house after seeing the Dr and then forgetting to take the medications, and then repeating the process again next time he went back to see the GP. It is exactly this situation that a person isn’t going to necessarily remember or admit to, but could lead to polypharmacy that could have dire consequences.
It is another situation that an HMR will identify and report back to the doctor, and potentially save a life with.

As a result, I have become a converted HMR advocate. While I had no interest in becoming accredited, I am now keen to see what it involves and how I can be of use in this context within the profession. This experience has truly shaped my professional life, and Mr DA will always stay with me as the patient who taught me the importance of HMR.

We had one case of an elderly gentleman (and he really was a gentle man)- Mr DA, who had been baffling his doctors and the pharmacy for months about his fluctuating INR. No one could work out what it was, and it was only after placement when I rang to enquire as to how this gentleman was going for my case review that I found out that an HMR had been done (finally after multiple requests to the GP) and Mr DA had been intermittently taking fish oil without telling anyone. 2CHBDJGUA:shared_process.name: raw
2CHBDJGUA:shared_process.object:
Before I went on placement in XXXX in the Summer break, I didn’t know how much the pharmacy means in the day-to-day life of the average elderly person, but also how important HMR is, and how it can save lives. I was familiar with the usual aspects of being older: more medical conditions that leads to more medications which leads to more medications being forgotten and the vicious cycle that ensues, but to see how this actually played out in everyday practice, with the consequences that it entailed, was eye opening, sad and exciting all at once.
We had one case of an elderly gentleman (and he really was a gentle man)- Mr DA, who had been baffling his doctors and the pharmacy for months about his fluctuating INR. No one could work out what it was, and it was only after placement when I rang to enquire as to how this gentleman was going for my case review that I found out that an HMR had been done (finally after multiple requests to the GP) and Mr DA had been intermittently taking fish oil without telling anyone. Mr DA would take a fish oil every other day or so, for a few days, when he remembered, which was a bit patchy at the best of times. As a result his INR would go up and then his warfarin would need to change in his Webster pack that we would pack for him, and then he would forget to take the fish oil for a while and his INR would go down, and his warfarin dose would need to change again- It was IT1 week 3 Cardiovascular right in front of my eyes!
However, most surprisingly to me, it highlighted and challenged my ideas about the importance of HMR (which I had learnt about in theory in PS2). While learning about HMR in PS2 I skeptical that having a medication review in the home would really contribute much to the report, and really that it was a bit of a gimmick. After all, medications are the same whether they are in the pharmacy or in the home.... Right? This case brought home the importance of seeing the medications in situ, as the fish oil was only found out about once it was seen in the cupboard along side Mr DA’s usual Webster pack. It could be said that the HMR potentially saved the life of this patient, as his fish oil is now being packed, and being taken consistently and the INR has settled.
I also came to see the effects of once cognitive impairment starts to set in from an objective point of view, which I wasn’t able to see previously. I saw from a pharmacist’s point of view how it becomes infinitely more difficult to help patients with self-managing their medication especially if non-intentional non-adherence becomes a problem. Mr DA wasn’t able to tell us that he was on fish oil, as he forgot that he had it, and that in itself presented as a fluctuating INR. He would also forget to take his medication from his Webster packs for weeks at a time also, returning the full, unused packs of Websters back to the pharmacy. This non-intentional non-adherence (as we learnt in PS2) was having therapeutic repercussions, probably compounding his medication related issues many times over.
However, the situation also brought back memories for me, of my father in his dementia having scripts filled with boxes of medications around the house after seeing the Dr and then forgetting to take the medications, and then repeating the process again next time he went back to see the GP. It is exactly this situation that a person isn’t going to necessarily remember or admit to, but could lead to polypharmacy that could have dire consequences.
It is another situation that an HMR will identify and report back to the doctor, and potentially save a life with.
As a result, I have become a converted HMR advocate. While I had no interest in becoming accredited, I am now keen to see what it involves and how I can be of use in this context within the profession. This experience has truly shaped my professional life, and Mr DA will always stay with me as the patient who taught me the importance of HMR.
